summary: Adding support for other tiling engines e.g. Bing Maps

comments.content:
Is it legal to display VE images in other applications? For google tiles it's not, so
I won't include it in the official code.

MapCruncher can produce Quadkey-organized tiles from any data source, without using VE 
images, so if you can build in support for generic URLs passing the quadkey as part of 
the URL for the tile, that would allow custom maps created by MapCruncher.

I have included the quadTree support but not the VE URLs. In future the info will not
be stored in an enum but in a sqlite database. Users can then supply their own schemes.

It is possible to support Bing Map only extending the OnlineTileSourceBase class (and implementing IStyledTileSource) in order to use Bing Map REST, the use the setTileSource method of the MapView to switch on this tile source.

I've spent the last week or so struggling to incorporate Bing Maps, but without success.  There are some similarities in the API, but not enough to make it really compatible with osmdroid/Google.
http://bingmapsandroidsdk.codeplex.com/

Thank's for this patch. It seems you've used the tiles directly rather than using the SDK.

Please do not add any more comments to this issue and use issue 236 instead.

A couple of comments (t ocarry forward to issue 236):

1. You could get the key from the manifest the same as the CloudMade key.
2. How does this fit with the Bing license?
3. Couldn't you extend QuadTreeTileSource instead of OnlineTileSourceBase?
